results.title: Baz and Barb's NZ holiday
results.brief_description: Reminisce with Baz and Barb over their New Zealand holiday through the somewhat amusing video images captured by the novice photographer Barb.

results.title: Not really morning people
results.creator_credit: Renee Rutgrink and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Can’t handle Mondays? Don’t think you can get out of bed tomorrow? Perhaps you’re not really a morning person. A cheeky tour into our morning journeys guided by a couple of observant experts we never really notice.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Renee Rutgrink and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television

results.title: Security
results.creator_credit: Renee Rutgrink and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: They are everywhere, shops, pubs, offices, but we never really notice them. Security guards. Sentinels of public order. Who are they? Cardboard cut-out muscle-men? Or real people? This short documentary about security guards Tunc and Fahim, briefly dips beyond the uniform to reveal their attitudes to both work and life, where they are from and where they are going.

results.title: Turn me on: the history of the vibrator
results.creator_credit: Catherine Chauchat, Warwick Burton and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Turn Me On explores the history of the vibrator. Through a group of sexpert characters, the documentary uncovers the socially camouflaged sex toy - hidden in the underwear drawer since it was invented over 120 years ago. Turn Me On reveals a social and sexual history that some people would prefer remained a secret.

results.title: Sammy Blue
results.creator_credit: Kim Farrant, Isabel Perez and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Sammy Blue is a young boy who wants to escape from the white noise of reality in his everyday life. If only he could be just like his goldfish “Blue” and swim around the bowl – forgetting everything, living moment by moment.
Features Andrew S. Gilbert as father, Claire Paradine as mother, William Balmford as Sammy and Zoe Carides as Mary.

results.title: Into the night
results.creator_credit: Tony Krawitz, Melissa Johnston, Rachel Clements and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A lost and fragile boy new to the streets. A wary teenager just thinking about the money. A wealthy man playing out a delicate and lonely game. Over one night their lives intersect in unexpected ways, blurring the line between betrayer and betrayed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Krawitz, Melissa Johnston, Rachel Clements and AFTRS

results.title: Your brother, my tidda
results.creator_credit: Kelrick Martin, Kathy Sport and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
“Coming out” to family, living with HIV and religion - some of the life changing situations faced by two Aboriginal gay men, Sam Barsah and Aaron Clark.
Sam has “come out” twice; first to his family about his sexuality and then about his HIV status. Like other indigenous gay men, he wants respect and understanding and only now, almost ten years later, does he feel able to speak openly about his story. Aaron is young and relatively new to Sydney. Growing up as a Jehovah’s Witness, he is looking for an alternative gay Christian group.
Using a contemporary blend of semi-observational filming, photos and animation, this short documentary about race and sexuality describes two very different stories of being Aboriginal and gay.
N.B. “Tidda” is an Aboriginal word for “sister”.

N.B. “Tidda” is an Aboriginal word for “sister”.

results.title: You dust mite be next
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, Jane Keneally, Kate Reidl, AFTRS and Chris Aronsten
results.brief_description: A docudrama about the evil little dust mite that plagues the world using up close and personal microscopic images, horror tales from victims and a biology lesson from experts Dr Ewan Tovey and Michael Morris.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darlene Johnson, Jane Keneally, Kate Reidl, AFTRS and Chris Aronsten
